questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive swelling in her mouth that she first noticed 5 years ago. The swelling was initially asymptomatic, but over the past month it has caused some difficulty chewing. She appears well and has no pain. She has not undergone any dental procedures in the past 5 years. She has bronchial asthma. Her only medication is an albuterol inhaler. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a 1.5-cm unilobular, bony hard, nontender mass with a smooth surface located in the midline of the hard palate. There is no cervical or submandibular lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The hyperplastic type of candidiasis may manifest as a palpable nodule on the oral mucosa. However, it is usually a white lesion with a rough surface and most commonly occurs on the inside of the cheeks or on the sides of the tongue, rather than the palate.

B) INCORRECT:

Pleomorphic adenoma usually manifests as a painless, firm mass and may involve the minor salivary glands of the palate. However, the tumor would not be bony hard on palpation. It most commonly develops in patients 40–60 years of age with a history of ionizing radiation or environmental/occupational exposure (e.g., rubber manufacturing, cosmetologists, nickel compound exposure), and is, therefore, less likely in this young patient without any risk factors.
Image Description:

Oral cavity of a patient, ventral view: A protrusion of the left lateral wall of the pharynx can be seen. Further diagnostics performed on the patient confirmed a pleomorphic adenoma of the parotid gland, which expanded into the parapharyngeal space.

C) INCORRECT:

Although necrotizing sialometaplasia may manifest as a palatal lesion, the lesion is usually concave and ulcerated. In addition, it most commonly affects patients around 50 years of age and is, therefore, less likely in this young woman.

D) INCORRECT:

A nasopalatine duct cyst may manifest as a midline palatal mass, most commonly in patients aged 30–60 years. However, the mass is usually fluctuant rather than bony hard, making this an unlikely diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

An abscess of the oral cavity is most commonly caused by the spread of an odontogenic infection. Although a palatal abscess commonly manifests as a localized swelling lateral or in the midline of the palate, it is usually fluctuant and painful rather than bony hard and nontender.

F) CORRECT:

The presence of a bony hard, nontender mass in the midline of the hard palate is consistent with torus palatinus, a benign bone tumor that most commonly occurs in adolescents or young adults. The overgrowth is typically asymptomatic, but it may lead to difficulties with chewing food or speaking once it reaches a certain size. The diagnosis of torus palatinus is usually made based on clinical presentation. Surgical removal should be considered if the mass interferes with speech or eating.
Image Description:

A bony protrusion covered with normal mucosa is visible as a bump in the midline of the hard palate.
questions.hint: This patient's findings are consistent with a common type of benign bony overgrowth.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man is brought to the physician because of increasing pain and swelling of the left knee for 2 months. The pain has awoken him from his sleep on multiple occasions. He tried ibuprofen but has had no relief of his symptoms. There is no family or personal history of serious illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, the left knee is mildly swollen and tender; range of motion is limited by pain. An x-ray of the left knee is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteosarcomas typically also occur in patients younger than 30 years, involve the ends of long bones, present with pain (particularly at night) and swelling, and may appear as an osteolytic lesion with cortical erosion on x-ray. However, the lesion would be ill-defined, with a wide transition zone between normal bone and the lesion, and an aggressive periosteal reaction (often with a sunburst appearance and Codman triangle), which is absent here, would be typical.
Image Description:

X-ray right knee (AP and lateral views) of a patient with osteosarcoma

An ill-defined cloud-like lesion with a wide zone of transition (green overlay) is seen in the distal femur. An aggressive type of periosteal reaction known as a Codman triangle (C) is visible medially. Additional aggressive periosteal reaction seen posteriorly has produced a sunburst pattern (S).

B) INCORRECT:

Chondrosarcomas may also appear at the ends of long bones as an osteolytic lesion with cortical erosion and can manifest with pain (particularly at night) and swelling. However, the lesion would be ill-defined with a moth-eaten appearance. Furthermore, spiculated, popcorn-like, or ring-and-arc calcifications are usually seen within the tumor. Moreover, chondrosarcomas occur in patients above the age of 50 years and more commonly affect the femur, pelvis, or proximal humerus; the tibia is not a typical site.
Image Description:

X-ray hips (AP view) of patient with left hip pain, swelling, gait instability, and restriction of movement

A mixed lytic and blastic lesion in the left hemipelvis is accompanied by a large soft tissue component. Indistinct margins and areas of cortical destruction suggest an aggressive lesion.

Further evaluation confirmed the diagnosis of chondrosarcoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Fibrous dysplasias typically occur in patients younger than 30 years (most commonly in pediatric patients), appear as a well-defined osteolytic lesion, and may cause pain or swelling. However, they usually occur in the diaphysis and/or metaphyseal-diaphyseal region and rarely involve the epiphysis. Although some degree of endosteal scalloping may occur, the cortex is usually intact throughout and no periosteal reaction is seen (unless a pathologic fracture occurs!).

D) INCORRECT:

Enchondromas typically occur in patients 20–40 years of age and appear on x-ray as a well-defined osteolytic lesion. However, enchondromas typically manifest with small lesions that involve the phalanges and are mostly asymptomatic. Although enchondromas can sometimes develop in long bones such as the femur and tibia, they usually appear at the metaphyses and rarely involve the epiphysis. Lastly, a periosteal reaction is not characteristic of enchondromas.
Image Description:

Anteroposterior x-ray of the left hand: oval area of reduced bone density in the distal third of the fifth metacarpal bone (circled area);
Diagnosis: enchondroma of the fifth metacarpal bone

E) INCORRECT:

Aneurysmal bone cysts typically occur in patients younger than 30 years and may also present with pain and swelling. An x-ray would show a well-defined osteolytic lesion that involves the ends of long bones (especially around the knee) and internal septations (soap-bubble appearance). However, the lesion typically balloons out beyond the contours of normal bone and has a sclerotic rim with a regularly thinned-out cortex, while this patient's lesion is nonexpansile in nature and shows irregular cortical thinning.
Image Description:

X-ray of the right knee joint (PA)

A sharply demarcated, osteolytic lesion (green area) with a thin sclerotic edge (white lines) can be seen in the lateral part of the distal femur. It is most likely an aneurysmal bone cyst, although the finding could also be unicameral bone cyst.

F) CORRECT:

Osteoclastomas (giant cell tumors of bone) are caused by a proliferation of osteoclastic giant cells (due to overactivity in the RANK signaling pathway). They have a peak incidence between the ages of 20 and 40 years and generally arise eccentrically in the epiphysis or metaphysis of long bones (usually distal femur or proximal tibia). Patients usually present with local pain and swelling, and occasionally pathological fractures or reduced range of motion. Osteoclastomas typically appear on x-ray as a well-defined osteolytic lesion with a soap-bubble appearance (due to trabecular remnants) and nonsclerotic margins, as seen in this patient. Despite the large size of the lesion, most lesions are benign, and the periosteal reaction is usually nonaggressive. A biopsy is indicated to confirm the diagnosis.

For localized disease, the treatment of choice is resection by wide-excision or intralesional curettage. Patients with an unresectable tumor or a marginally resected tumor should undergo radiotherapy and/or systemic therapy with denosumab.

G) INCORRECT:

Chondromyxoid fibromas typically occur in patients younger than 30 years, are most commonly located at the upper end of the tibia, and may result in pain and swelling. On x-ray, they appear as a well-defined osteolytic lesion in the metaphysis (that may extend into the epiphysis) and may also show a soap-bubble appearance (due to pseudo-trabeculations). However, chondromyxoid fibromas occur within the cortex (eccentric lesion), unlike the central lesion seen in this patient, have sclerotic margins, and do not result in a periosteal reaction (unless a pathological fracture occurs!).

H) INCORRECT:

Ewing sarcomas also occur in patients younger than 30 years (with a peak between 10–15 years), would present with pain (particularly at night) and swelling, and may appear as an osteolytic lesion with cortical erosion on x-ray. However, the lesion typically occurs in the diaphysis and/or metaphysis, and rarely involves the epiphysis. Furthermore, the lesion would be ill-defined, with a wide transition zone between normal bone and the lesion (unlike the well-defined geographic lesion in this patient), and an aggressive, lamellated periosteal reaction (onion-skin appearance) is usually present.
Image Description:

X-ray knee and lower leg (lateral view) of a child with Ewing sarcoma

A lytic permeative lesion (green overlay) in the proximal tibial diaphysis has a wide zone of transition. It is accompanied by lamellated periosteal reaction that results in an onion skin appearance (red overlay).

Illustration: comparison of radiographic patterns of bone destruction
questions.hint: A biopsy of the mass would show multinucleated giant cells.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a 1-month history of pain and increasing swelling over her scalp. She has not had any trauma to the area. There is no family or personal history of serious illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a 3-cm solitary, tender mass over the right parietal bone. An x-ray of the skull shows a solitary osteolytic lesion. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.9 g/dL


Leukocyte count
7300/mm3



Serum



 Na+

136 mEq/L


 K+

3.7 mEq/L


 Cl-

103 mEq/L


 Ca2+

9.1 mg/dL


 Glucose
71 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Multiple myeloma causes anemia and calvarial osteolytic lesions with bone pain. However, this condition most commonly manifests in patients older than 40 years of age. Additionally, hypercalcemia is typically present and skull involvement is usually associated with multiple osteolytic lesions; this patient has a solitary osteolytic lesion.
Image Description:

X-ray skull (lateral view) of a patient with a history of multiple myeloma

Multiple punched-out lytic lesions (examples indicated by green overlay) are visible. This appearance is termed “raindrop sign” from the resemblance of these lesions to raindrops splashing upon hitting a surface.

An expanded differential of lucent skull lesions includes osteoporosis of aging, hyperparathyroidism, metastatic disease, anemias (e.g., sickle cell and thalassemia), and the lytic phase of Paget disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Severe hyperparathyroidism, which is typically caused by parathyroid adenoma or severe end-stage kidney disease (ESKD), can cause painful, osteolytic, calvarial lesions (osteitis fibrosa cystica). Hyperparathyroidism (especially secondary to ESKD) is also associated with anemia. However, parathyroid adenoma typically occurs in women older than 50 years of age and manifests with hypercalcemia; there is also no history of CKD in this patient. Moreover, calvarial osteitis fibrosa cystica typically manifests with multiple osteolytic lesions interspersed with regions of sclerosis (“pepperpot” skull), unlike the single osteolytic lesion in this patient.
Image Description:

X-ray hands (PA view)

A well-defined, expansile lytic lesion with cortical thinning (brown tumor) is present in the distal diaphysis of the index finger metacarpal (white arrow). A similar but smaller lesion is present in the proximal diaphysis of the middle phalanx of the middle finger (blue arrow).

Brown tumors typically appear as circumscribed expansile lytic lesions without reactive bone formation.

C) CORRECT:

Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is a rare disorder that most commonly affects children 5–10 years of age. LCH manifests with single or multiple osteolytic lesions that cause bone pain and swelling. The skull is the most commonly affected bone in children, although other bones such as the long bones, vertebrae, and ribs can also be affected. LCH can also manifest with systemic findings such as rash, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and central diabetes insipidus. Secondary anemia may develop in patients with bone marrow involvement. Affected individuals typically have normal serum calcium levels.

See “Overview cysts and hemangiomas” table.
Image Description:

X-ray skull (left: lateral view; right: PA view) of a child with Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH)

Well-defined lytic lesions without sclerotic margins are seen in the frontoparietal and high-parietal regions of the calvarium (example indicated by green overlay).

Various conditions can cause lytic skull lesions. LCH lesions are typically rounded or ovoid in shape and have nonsclerotic well-defined margins. Edges may be beveled as a result of uneven destruction of the inner and outer tables. Coalescence of enlarging lesions can produce a geographic appearance.

D) INCORRECT:

Ewing sarcoma typically manifests during childhood or adolescence as an osteolytic lesion with localized pain and swelling. Anemia may also be seen in some patients. However, Ewing sarcoma typically affects the diaphyses of long bones, such as the femur or tibia, not the skull.
Image Description:

X-ray knee and lower leg (lateral view) of a child with Ewing sarcoma

A lytic permeative lesion (green overlay) in the proximal tibial diaphysis has a wide zone of transition. It is accompanied by lamellated periosteal reaction that results in an onion skin appearance (red overlay).

Illustration: comparison of radiographic patterns of bone destruction

E) INCORRECT:

An aneurysmal bone cyst appears on x-ray as an osteolytic lesion, and it can cause localized pain and swelling. However, peak incidence occurs during adolescence, and the cyst most commonly localizes to the spine, femur, or tibia. Moreover, aneurysmal bone cyst is not associated with anemia.
Image Description:

X-ray of the right knee joint (PA)

A sharply demarcated, osteolytic lesion (green area) with a thin sclerotic edge (white lines) can be seen in the lateral part of the distal femur. It is most likely an aneurysmal bone cyst, although the finding could also be unicameral bone cyst.

F) INCORRECT:

Ossifying fibroma typically manifests during childhood as an osteolytic lesion; localized swelling is seen in some patients. However, ossifying fibromas most commonly affect the tibia and/or fibula, and they are typically painless. Additionally, this diagnosis would not explain the patient's anemia.
Image Description:

Viscerocranium on CT (left: axial view; right: 3D reformation)

A large lesion (green overlay) is visible on the right front side of the mandible. As a result of that lesion, the buccal and lingual cortical plate is thinned and expanded.

In the presence of histopathological signs of ossifying fibroma, these findings confirm the diagnosis.

G) INCORRECT:

Giant-cell tumor of bone manifests with localized pain and swelling, and it appears on x-ray as an osteolytic lesion. However, this tumor typically manifests in patients older than 20 years of age and affects the epiphyses of long bones, usually around the knee. Additionally, this diagnosis would not explain the patient's anemia.
Image Description:

X-ray left knee (AP view) of a 23-year-old patient with a giant cell tumor (osteoclastoma)

A lucent lesion in the proximal tibia (green overlay) has a bubbly appearance (examples indicated by outlines) and well-defined nonsclerotic margins. The cortex shows endosteal scalloping (examples indicated by arrowheads). The growth plate is closed and the lesion extends to the subarticular bone.

Giant cell tumor is one of several bone lesions that can have a bubbly appearance. Most giant cell tumors are eccentrically located, although large lesions may appear central. They are typically located at the ends of the long bones in the region of the closed growth plate. Some giant cell tumors contain aneurysmal bone cyst components.
questions.hint: A biopsy of this mass, which is needed to confirm the diagnosis, will show heterogeneous collections of polygonal, eosinophilic cells that contain Birbeck granules.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of progressive left leg pain for the past 2 months, which has started to interfere with his sleep. His mother has been giving him ibuprofen at night for “growing pains,” but his symptoms have not improved. One week before the pain started, the patient was hit in the thigh by a baseball, which caused his leg to become red and swollen for several days. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows marked tenderness along the left mid-femur. His gait is normal. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 21,000/mm3 and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 68 mm/h. An x-ray of the left lower extremity shows multiple lytic lesions in the middle third of the femur, and the surrounding cortex is covered by several layers of new bone. A biopsy of the left femur shows small round blue cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteosarcoma typically occurs in the long bones of individuals between 10–20 years of age and presents similarly, with painful swelling and progressive symptoms over the course of a few weeks to months. However, osteosarcoma usually arises at the metaphysis, has a mixed lytic-sclerotic appearance, and involves an aggressive periosteal reaction with perpendicular new bone growth (resulting in a sunburst pattern and/or Codman's triangle) and irregular cortical destruction. A biopsy would reveal poorly formed trabecular bone.
Image Description:

X-ray right knee (AP and lateral views) of a patient with osteosarcoma

An ill-defined cloud-like lesion with a wide zone of transition (green overlay) is seen in the distal femur. An aggressive type of periosteal reaction known as a Codman triangle (C) is visible medially. Additional aggressive periosteal reaction seen posteriorly has produced a sunburst pattern (S).

B) INCORRECT:

Chondrosarcoma appears as a focal osteolytic lesion on x-ray and may present with painful swelling. However, chondrosarcoma is extremely rare in patients < 30 years old and classically involves the pelvis, the proximal femur, or the proximal humerus. An x-ray would also show characteristic ring-and-arc or popcorn calcifications. A biopsy would show hyaline cartilage with a chondroid matrix and atypical binucleated cells.
Image Description:

X-ray hips (AP view) of patient with left hip pain, swelling, gait instability, and restriction of movement

A mixed lytic and blastic lesion in the left hemipelvis is accompanied by a large soft tissue component. Indistinct margins and areas of cortical destruction suggest an aggressive lesion.

Further evaluation confirmed the diagnosis of chondrosarcoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Osteochondroma typically presents as a painless bone swelling in the metaphyses of long bones, rather than the diaphysis as seen here. An x-ray would reveal a metaphyseal bony protrusion with variable degrees of sclerosis and a cartilaginous cap.
Image Description:

Bony exostosis on the lateral right distal tibial metaphysis and deformation of the right fibula

D) INCORRECT:

Chondroblastoma typically affects patients < 20 years old, appears as a lytic lesion in a long bone on x-ray, and may present with pain and swelling due to associated edema. However, chondroblastoma almost always occurs in the epiphysis and appears as single lytic lesions with well-defined margins that typically have a solid periosteal reaction (unlike the multiple diaphyseal lytic lesions and lamellated periosteal reaction seen here). Symptoms are more indolent and progress slowly over a period of 1–2 years. A biopsy would show a bluish chondroid matrix and a characteristic “chicken-wire” calcification, which is caused by calcium deposition around the chondroblasts.
Image Description:

X-ray of the right talocrural joint (a. AP view; b. lateral view)

An oval osteolytic lesion is visible in the posterolateral part of the distal tibial epiphysis.

This is the typical appearance of chondroblastoma.

E) CORRECT:

Ewing sarcoma typically occurs in patients < 20 years of age and involves the diaphysis of long bones. An x-ray usually reveals a tumor with multiple lytic lesions that may extend into the surrounding soft tissue and an aggressive lamellated periosteal reaction, giving rise to the classic onion skin appearance on x-ray (see “Overview of primary malignant bone tumors” table). A biopsy reveals small, round undifferentiated cells that appear dark blue on an H&E stain because these cells have a large nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio, and the nucleus stains blue with hematoxylin. Patients also often have systemic features such as fever, ↑ ESR, and leukocytosis. A t(11;22) chromosomal translocation is found in approximately 90% of cases of Ewing sarcoma, resulting in expression of fusion protein EWS-FLI 1.
Image Description:

X-ray knee and lower leg (lateral view) of a child with Ewing sarcoma

A lytic permeative lesion (green overlay) in the proximal tibial diaphysis has a wide zone of transition. It is accompanied by lamellated periosteal reaction that results in an onion skin appearance (red overlay).

Illustration: comparison of radiographic patterns of bone destruction

F) INCORRECT:

Osteoid osteoma typically affects patients < 30 years old in the diaphysis of a long bone and typically presents with nocturnal pain. However, an x-ray would usually show a single lytic nidus (< 2 cm in size) surrounded by a dense sclerotic reaction (unlike the multiple lytic lesions and lamellated periosteal reaction seen here). Also, pain would be relieved dramatically by aspirin or NSAIDs such as ibuprofen (since pain is caused by prostaglandins produced in the nidus).
Image Description:

X-ray right hip (AP view) of a 12-year-old boy

A small lucent nidus (hatched green overlay) in the medial proximal femur is accompanied by reactive sclerosis and cortical thickening (green overlay).

The appearance is compatible with osteoid osteoma, although other conditions (e.g., intracortical abscess, stress fracture, osteoblastoma) can mimic osteoid osteoma and must be distinguished on the basis of the clinical presentation and additional imaging.
questions.hint: Genetic testing of the biopsy sample will likely reveal a t(11;22) chromosomal translocation.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of progressive right knee pain for the past 3 months. He reports that the pain is worse at night and while doing sports at school. He has not had any trauma to the knee or any previous problems with his joints. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the right knee shows mild swelling and tenderness without warmth or erythema; the range of motion is limited. He walks with an antalgic gait. Laboratory studies show an alkaline phosphatase of 180 U/L and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 80 mm/h. An x-ray of the right knee is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteoclastoma may also manifest with pain and swelling of a long bone, but it usually occurs in patients 20–40 years of age. Although the tumor may be located in the metaphysis, as in this patient, the epiphysis is typically involved, with the tumor lying in close proximity to the articular surface. An x-ray would also reveal a large, expansile lytic lesion with a thin layer of cortex and a loculated or “soap-bubble” appearance within the tumor due to trabecular remnants. The periosteal reaction would also not be as aggressive as what is seen in this patient's x-ray.
Image Description:

X-ray left knee (AP view) of a 23-year-old patient with a giant cell tumor (osteoclastoma)

A lucent lesion in the proximal tibia (green overlay) has a bubbly appearance (examples indicated by outlines) and well-defined nonsclerotic margins. The cortex shows endosteal scalloping (examples indicated by arrowheads). The growth plate is closed and the lesion extends to the subarticular bone.

Giant cell tumor is one of several bone lesions that can have a bubbly appearance. Most giant cell tumors are eccentrically located, although large lesions may appear central. They are typically located at the ends of the long bones in the region of the closed growth plate. Some giant cell tumors contain aneurysmal bone cyst components.

B) INCORRECT:

Ewing sarcoma occurs in patients younger than 20 years of age and manifests similarly, with painful swelling that is exacerbated at night, increased ESR, increased alkaline phosphatase, and an aggressive periosteal reaction. However, the tumor typically occurs in the diaphysis of long bones, and an x-ray would reveal a tumor with multiple lytic lesions and a lamellated periosteal reaction (giving rise to an onion skin appearance on x-ray), in contrast to the mixed lytic-sclerotic lesion with a sunburst periosteal reaction.
Image Description:

X-ray knee and lower leg (lateral view) of a child with Ewing sarcoma

A lytic permeative lesion (green overlay) in the proximal tibial diaphysis has a wide zone of transition. It is accompanied by lamellated periosteal reaction that results in an onion skin appearance (red overlay).

Illustration: comparison of radiographic patterns of bone destruction

C) INCORRECT:

Chordoma is typically seen in the axial skeleton of patients older than 50 years. The onset of symptoms is more indolent (usually occurring over a few years), and patients present with back or neck pain and/or slowly progressive neurological deficits. An x-ray would reveal a well-defined lytic lesion with marginal sclerosis and calcifications within the tumor (due to bony sequestrations).

D) INCORRECT:

Osteochondroma is the most common primary benign bone tumor. While it is more common among males 10–20 years of age, it typically manifests as a painless bone swelling near the ends of long bones. Inflammatory markers, such as ESR, are usually not increased. An x-ray would reveal a bony protrusion with variable degrees of sclerosis and a cartilaginous cap.
Image Description:

X-ray of the right upper arm

Patchy, calcified, mushroom-shaped exostosis on the surface of the humerus.
Displacement of the adjacent soft tissue (arrows) without infiltration (sharp demarcation).

E) INCORRECT:

Chondrosarcoma also often occurs in the metaphysis of long bones such as the femur and may manifest as a painful swelling. However, chondrosarcoma usually occurs in patients older than 50 years. An x-ray typically shows a focal osteolytic lesion with characteristic ring and arcs or popcorn calcifications and/or endosteal scalloping.
Image Description:

X-ray hips (AP view) of patient with left hip pain, swelling, gait instability, and restriction of movement

A mixed lytic and blastic lesion in the left hemipelvis is accompanied by a large soft tissue component. Indistinct margins and areas of cortical destruction suggest an aggressive lesion.

Further evaluation confirmed the diagnosis of chondrosarcoma.

F) CORRECT:

Osteosarcoma typically occurs in adolescents and young adults and involves the metaphysis of long bones. Patients present with swelling and pain that is worse at night and during activity. Decreased range of motion and gait abnormalities are also common. X-ray usually reveals a poorly defined lytic-sclerotic tumor at the metaphysis with irregular cortical destruction and an aggressive periosteal reaction with perpendicular new bone growth, resulting in a sunburst pattern and/or Codman triangle (see “Overview of primary malignant bone tumors” table). Alkaline phosphatase is often elevated in patients with osteosarcoma and is considered a poor prognostic marker.

The initial workup of this patient involves a contrast-enhanced MRI of the affected bone followed by a core needle or surgical biopsy for histological diagnosis. A chest CT, as well as a PET scan or a bone scan, should be performed to look for metastases. Definitive therapy consists of wide surgical resection of the tumor.
questions.hint: This patient's age and the location and radiological features of his bone lesion raise concern for the most common primary bone malignancy.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for the evaluation of pubic hair development. She has a history of a fracture in each leg and in her right arm. Her performance at school is good. There is no family history of serious illness. She takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Genital examination shows coarse, dark hair along the labia. The breast glands are enlarged and the breast buds extend beyond the areolar diameter. There are several hyperpigmented macules with rough, serpiginous borders of different sizes on the right lower and upper extremities. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) manifests with recurrent bone fractures due to osteopenia. However, precocious puberty and café au lait spots are not commonly seen in OI. Furthermore, this patient lacks further findings of OI such as blue sclerae, growth retardation, hearing loss, and brittle, opalescent teeth.
Image Description:

The sclerae show a distinct blue-grey tint.

B) CORRECT:

The triad of pathological fractures, café au lait spots, and precocious puberty is highly suggestive of McCune-Albright syndrome. Pathological fractures result from polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, which generally manifests with well-defined, lobulated lesions with a thin cortex and a radiolucent ground-glass appearance on x-ray of the long bones. Laboratory studies typically show elevated alkaline phosphatase along with normal calcium, PTH, and 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D levels. In McCune-Albright syndrome, precocious puberty is most commonly seen in girls; it is caused by excess estrogen production in girls and testosterone in boys (peripheral precocity). Treatment is symptomatic and includes surgery for pathological fractures and the administration of bisphosphonates. The medical management of precocious puberty consists of estrogen synthesis blockers (e.g., ketoconazole, testolactone) or selective estrogen receptor modulators (e.g., tamoxifen) in girls and antiandrogens in combination with aromatase inhibitors in boys.
Image Description:

There is a flat, hyperpigmented, irregularly shaped macule visible on the patient's forearm. These macules are also known as “café-au-lait spots.”

Unilateral café-au-lait spots in patients with precocious onset of puberty suggest McCune-Albright syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) can manifest with café au lait spots and skeletal abnormalities (e.g., fractures, bowing of long bones). However, this patient lacks further typical findings of NF1 such as neurofibromas, optic glioma, Lisch nodules, or a family history of NF1 in a first-degree relative. While pathological fractures in NF1 are caused by cortical thinning of long bones, fractures in this patient's condition result from fibrous dysplasia.
Image Description:

Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

D) INCORRECT:

In select types of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), patients may present with precocious puberty due to errors in steroidogenesis. Patients with CAH also have an increased risk of osteoporosis and pathological fractures due to the need for lifelong glucocorticoid-replacement therapy. However, café au lait spots are not a feature of CAH. Furthermore, other typical features of CAH, such as hypotension and severe electrolyte abnormalities (e.g., hyponatremia, hypochloremia, hyperkalemia), caused by decreased production of aldosterone and cortisol, are absent in this patient. Lastly, if left untreated, CAH can lead to prenatal virilization in girls, which would likely be detected at birth; screening for CAH is currently recommended for all neonates.

E) INCORRECT:

Tuberous sclerosis can manifest with café au lait spots. However, the condition typically manifests along with ash-leaf spots, adenoma sebaceum, Shagreen patches, retinal lesions, cardiac rhabdomyomas, infantile seizures, developmental delay, and intellectual impairment, none of which are seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient has a history of several bone fractures and presents with signs of precocious puberty and café au lait spots. These features are associated with a specific medical condition.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of worsening headaches and a rash for 2 weeks. His mother reports that the rash started on his abdomen and diffusely spread to other areas. Over the past 2 months, he has had recurrent episodes of otitis media. Examination shows a diffuse, erythematous, papular rash involving the groin, abdomen, chest, and back. His cervical lymph nodes are palpable bilaterally. An x-ray of the skull shows well-defined lytic lesions of the left occipital bone and the mastoid bone. Electron microscopy of a biopsy of the patient's posterior cervical lymph nodes shows polygonal cells with organelles shaped like tennis rackets. The cells stain positive for S-100. Clonal proliferation of which of the following types of cells is most likely seen on microscopy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Natural killer cells are lymphocytes that can be found in lymph nodes in the setting of infection. These cells do not show Birbeck granules on electron microscopy. Moreover, they are not involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's underlying disorder and are unrelated to the findings of rash, recurrent otitis media, and lytic skull lesions.

B) INCORRECT:

B cells can be found in a typical lymph node biopsy; a clonal proliferation of B cells can be seen in lymph node biopsies of B-cell lymphomas. Although lymphoma can cause lymphadenopathy, it does not cause a rash, recurrent otitis media, or lytic skull lesions. Moreover, lymphoma is rare in childhood. B cells do not show Birbeck granules on electron microscopy.

C) CORRECT:

Langerhans cells are macrophages of the skin and lymphoid tissue that present antigens to other cells of the immune system. Clonal proliferation of these cells results in Langerhans cell histiocytosis, a condition that causes lytic skull lesions and a skin rash, as seen in this patient. Recurrent otitis media can occur if the mastoid process is involved. Langerhans cells express CD1a, which mediates antigen presentation, and S-100, which is used as a tumor marker for cells derived from the neural crest.

Langerhans cell histiocytosis can rarely cause hypopituitarism, which can manifest with central diabetes insipidus.
Image Description:

Electron micrograph of a Langerhans cell

The Birbeck granules are visible as tennis-racket-shaped structures within the cytoplasm (illustration; examples indicated by green overlay).

Birbeck granules are a diagnostic marker for Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

D) INCORRECT:

An accumulation of eosinophils in lymph nodes can be seen in the setting of lymphoma and parasitic infection. Though eosinophils do express S-100 and eosinophilia can manifest with an urticarial rash, they are not involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's underlying disorder and are unrelated to the findings of recurrent otitis media and lytic skull lesions. Moreover, eosinophils do not show Birbeck granules on electron microscopy.

E) INCORRECT:

A clonal proliferation of plasma cells can be found in lymph node biopsies of multiple myeloma, which can manifest with osteolytic lesions. However, this condition is rare in childhood. In addition, it does not cause a rash or recurrent otitis media. Moreover, plasma cells do not show Birbeck granules on electron microscopy.
questions.hint: The tennis racket-shaped organelles seen on electron microscopy are Birbeck granules.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 2-month history of progressive swelling of his right upper arm. He has otherwise been healthy. Medical history is unremarkable and he takes no medications. Immunizations are up-to-date. He appears well-nourished and well-developed. He is at the 60th percentile for height and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an immobile mass on the right proximal humerus that is nontender to palpation. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 10 mm/h and alkaline phosphatase is 35 U/L. An x-ray shows a 3-cm sessile bony protrusion with a cartilage cap on the proximal metaphysis of the right humerus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chondrosarcoma can develop in male individuals and may involve the proximal metaphysis of the humerus. However, chondrosarcomas most commonly develop in individuals > 50 years of age and manifest with progressive pain that worsens at night, tender swelling of the affected area with erythema, pathologic fractures, and elevated inflammatory markers. Moreover, x-ray usually shows a lytic lesion with a “moth-eaten” appearance, intralesional calcifications, and endosteal scalloping.
Image Description:

X-ray hips (AP view) of patient with left hip pain, swelling, gait instability, and restriction of movement

A mixed lytic and blastic lesion in the left hemipelvis is accompanied by a large soft tissue component. Indistinct margins and areas of cortical destruction suggest an aggressive lesion.

Further evaluation confirmed the diagnosis of chondrosarcoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Osteoid osteoma can develop in male individuals 4–25 years of age and may involve the proximal metaphysis of the humerus. However, affected individuals typically present with dull, constant pain that worsens at night. Moreover, x-ray most commonly shows a bony mass with a radiolucent core surrounded by perifocal sclerosis, rather than a sessile bony protrusion with a cartilage cap.
Image Description:

X-ray right hip (AP view) of a 12-year-old boy

A small lucent nidus (hatched green overlay) in the medial proximal femur is accompanied by reactive sclerosis and cortical thickening (green overlay).

The appearance is compatible with osteoid osteoma, although other conditions (e.g., intracortical abscess, stress fracture, osteoblastoma) can mimic osteoid osteoma and must be distinguished on the basis of the clinical presentation and additional imaging.

C) INCORRECT:

Ewing sarcoma can develop in male individuals 10–20 years of age and may involve the humerus. However, the diaphysis is usually affected, not the metaphysis. In addition, affected individuals typically present with progressive localized pain that worsens at night, tender swelling of the affected area with erythema, B symptoms, and elevated inflammatory markers, none of which are seen here. Lastly, x-ray typically shows lytic bone lesions and periosteum with an “onion skin” appearance.
Image Description:

X-ray knee and lower leg (lateral view) of a child with Ewing sarcoma

A lytic permeative lesion (green overlay) in the proximal tibial diaphysis has a wide zone of transition. It is accompanied by lamellated periosteal reaction that results in an onion skin appearance (red overlay).

Illustration: comparison of radiographic patterns of bone destruction

D) INCORRECT:

Osteosarcoma can develop in male individuals 10–30 years of age and may involve the proximal metaphysis of the humerus. However, affected individuals typically present with localized, progressive pain that worsens at night, tender swelling of the affected area with erythema, B symptoms, and elevated inflammatory markers, none of which is seen here. Lastly, x-ray usually shows a mixed osteolytic and osteosclerotic lesion with an aggressive periosteal reaction (sunburst appearance or Codman triangle).
Image Description:

X-ray of the right femorotibial joint (AP view) of a 17-year-old male patient

A sclerotic outgrowth of the bone (green overlay) surrounded by osteolytic destruction of medullary and cortical bone (red overlay) is visible on the medial metaphysis of the femur.

The periosteum over the lesion is noncontinuous (dashed line), indicating rapid growth of the bone lesion.

This appearance of a mixed osteosclerotic and osteolytic lesion in the metaphyses of long bones is characteristic of osteosarcoma.

E) CORRECT:

Osteochondroma, which develops in the metaphysis of long bones (e.g., proximal humerus, distal femur), is the most common benign bone tumor. Osteochondromas have a peak incidence between 10 and 30 years of age and most commonly affect male individuals. While most affected individuals present with a painless palpable mass near a joint, they can also develop localized pain, limited range of motion, bone deformities, and pathologic fractures. Characteristic radiographic findings include a pedunculated or sessile bony protrusion with a cartilage cap.

Solitary osteochondromas, as seen here, have a very low chance of malignant transformation (approx. 1%) and usually require no further treatment. Regular monitoring may be indicated in patients with multiple osteochondromas, which have a higher chance of malignant transformation (approx. 5%). Surgical removal may be considered in patients who are symptomatic, develop pathologic fractures, or have growing tumors.
Image Description:

X-ray of the right upper arm

Patchy, calcified, mushroom-shaped exostosis on the surface of the humerus.
Displacement of the adjacent soft tissue (arrows) without infiltration (sharp demarcation).

F) INCORRECT:

Chondroblastoma can develop in male individuals 10–20 years of age and may involve the proximal humerus. However, the epiphysis is usually affected, not the metaphysis, and affected individuals typically present with constant joint pain and swelling. Moreover, x-ray usually shows a well-defined osteolytic lesion with a sclerotic rim.
Image Description:

X-ray of the right talocrural joint (a. AP view; b. lateral view)

An oval osteolytic lesion is visible in the posterolateral part of the distal tibial epiphysis.

This is the typical appearance of chondroblastoma.
questions.hint: In an otherwise healthy patient with normal ESR and alkaline phosphatase levels, a painless bone mass indicates a benign bone tumor.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man presents for his annual well visit. He is generally healthy and wears well-fitting lower dentures.
Physical examination reveals an asymptomatic, hard mass on his hard palate (figure). The mass is covered with normal-appearing mucosa. The patient reports that he has had the mass for most of his life with no recent changes. He reports no pain, numbness, bleeding, or unintentional weight loss.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Application of topical glucocorticoids twice daily for 7 days
Reassurance that this is a benign condition and does not require treatment
Referral to dentistry for refitting of dentures
CT of the head to determine depth of invasion of the lesion
Punch biopsy of the lesion to exclude malignancy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Application of topical glucocorticoids would not change the lesion and is not indicated.

B) CORRECT:

Torus palatinus is a common oral exostosis that occurs in approximately 10% to 30% of adults and has a hereditary component. Diagnosis is made clinically on the basis of typical location and appearance of the mass. Imaging is not required for diagnosis.

Excision is typically required only if the mass interferes with oral appliances, such as dentures, or causes ulcerations from chewing hard foods. Because this patient reports no symptoms, has well-fitting dentures, and has observed no recent growth of the lesion, no treatment or referral is needed.

Application of topical glucocorticoids would not change the lesion and is not indicated.

Key learning point: Asymptomatic torus palatinus is a common, benign condition that does not have the potential for malignant transformation and requires only reassurance.

C) INCORRECT:

Because this patient reports no symptoms, has well-fitting dentures, and has observed no recent growth of the lesion, no treatment or referral is needed.

D) INCORRECT:

Torus palatinus is a common oral exostosis that occurs in approximately 10% to 30% of adults and has a hereditary component. Diagnosis is made clinically on the basis of typical location and appearance of the mass. Imaging is not required for diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Torus palatinus is a common oral exostosis that occurs in approximately 10% to 30% of adults and has a hereditary component. Diagnosis is made clinically on the basis of typical location and appearance of the mass.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy presents with a soft, egg-sized mass on the left side of his head that his mother first noticed 2 weeks ago, when he started complaining of pain in this area. She initially thought he must have bumped his head, but the swelling has not resolved and seems to be bothering him even more. He has had no fevers. His medical history is significant for moderate eczema on his face, chest, and scalp; this condition is being treated with topical glucocorticoids and emollients but seems to be worsening. He has not traveled recently.
On examination, he is physically well developed but has a soft, skin-covered mass on the left parietal region of his head. The mass is nonerythematous but exquisitely painful to the touch, and there is a palpable indentation in the skull underlying it. The patient’s mucous membranes are tacky, and he has mild tachycardia (heart rate, 115 beats per minute). He has a flaking, erythematous rash on his face, arms, and chest, and he has shotty cervical lymphadenopathy.
A skull radiograph reveals a lytic, punched-out lesion in the region near the painful mass.
A complete blood count, electrolyte panel, skeletal survey, and chest radiograph are ordered, and a tissue biopsy is scheduled.
Which one of the following concurrent syndromes is this patient most likely to have?

choices.text: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neither opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome nor Horner syndrome is a typical feature of LCH. Horner syndrome may occur in a variety of malignant and nonmalignant disorders of the central nervous system and spine, as well as in rare primary lung cancers.

B) CORRECT:

A lytic bone mass on the skull of a young child with chronic eczema or seborrhea should raise suspicion for Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH). The most common clinical manifestation of LCH in children younger than 5 years is isolated bone pain, and lytic scalp lesions are a common initial site of pain. More than half of affected young children also present with dermatologic symptoms, frequently eczema or chronic seborrhea.

Other presenting symptoms vary, depending on the organs involved and the lesion sites; they may include diffuse bone pain, abdominal pain, dyspnea if there is pleural involvement, a rash or swelling around the eyes, mandibular pain or lesions, or dental and oropharyngeal lesions. The most common endocrinopathy in patients with LCH is diabetes insipidus, which typically manifests with excess thirst and urination.

Key learning point: A lytic bone mass in a young child with chronic eczema or seborrhea should raise suspicion for Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome occurs when a mediastinal mass creates obstruction of the trachea and the large vessels of the superior mediastinum. The most common malignant causes of SVC syndrome in children are lymphomas and leukemias; LCH is less likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Neither opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome nor Horner syndrome is a typical feature of LCH. Opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome is classically seen in patients with neuroblastoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Although there are tumors that secrete antidiuretic hormone, the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) is more frequently related to cancer chemotherapy than to cancer itself. SIADH is not likely to be a presenting sign in a patient with newly diagnosed LCH.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old male basketball player reports a 9-month history of right hip pain that has been worse at night and sometimes wakes him from sleep. He reports no trauma. Taking ibuprofen relieves the pain. He has been able to continue participating in his normal activities but does experience some pain with running and jumping.
On physical examination, he appears well. There is no palpable mass or swelling over the hip or thigh. He has a regular gait and full range of motion at the hip but notes pain on abduction and external rotation.
Plain radiographs of the hip are normal. However, T1-weighted MRI images show an area of increased signal within the bone marrow extending from the level of the growth plate, approximately 12 cm down the femoral shaft (figure 1).
In addition, CT of the hip shows a well-circumscribed, round, lytic lesion with central mineralization, surrounded by a zone of sclerosis (figure 2).
Which one of the following diagnoses is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Osteoid osteoma is a benign bone tumor that most commonly arises in long bones. Affected patients usually report severe, localized pain that is worse at night and is dramatically improved with salicylates or other nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). On imaging, the lesion is characteristically <2 cm in size, well-circumscribed, and round with an osteolytic center and surrounding zone of sclerosis. Because plain radiographs may miss the lesion (as in this case), MRI or CT may be necessary, and a bone scan will show uptake. CT is the best modality for diagnosis because it can best characterize the lesions. Although most osteoid osteomas self-resolve within several years, those that remain symptomatic (with refractory pain or functional impairments) despite NSAIDs may require surgical resection.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in an adolescent who has unilateral hip pain that is worse at night and is responsive to nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug therapy — and whose imaging shows a round, lytic lesion in the femur with central mineralization — is osteoid osteoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Osteoblastoma is a relatively rare, benign bone tumor that typically manifests with progressive pain that is not responsive to NSAIDs. It is typically larger than osteoid osteoma (>2 cm in size) and more locally aggressive; it can arise in the spine, sacrum, and metadiaphyseal regions of long bones. On imaging, osteoblastomas typically appear as well-defined, mixed lytic and blastic masses with sclerotic margins.

C) INCORRECT:

Osteosarcoma is a rare malignant bone tumor that often occurs in long-bone metaphyses. Plain films may show internal bone formation, Codman triangle (characteristic periosteal reaction forming triangles of reactive bone at the edges of the lesion), and a sunburst appearance (ossification occurring in a pattern that is perpendicular to the surface of the bone).

D) INCORRECT:

Enchondroma is an abnormal growth of cartilage within bone and most commonly occurs in the long bones of the hands and feet. On plain films, it appears as a lytic lesion with a calcified chondroid matrix. Most enchondromas are asymptomatic unless a fracture is present.

E) INCORRECT:

Ewing sarcoma, another malignant tumor of bone, often occurs in the diaphyseal region of the long bones and can also be found in the pelvis and spine. On plain radiographs, it often appears with poor margins and a mixed lytic and sclerotic appearance. Plain films may show an onion-skin appearance created by the lamellated periosteal reaction, which is suggestive of the diagnosis.
